body: This error seems to come directly from overlord. I receive it as http response when submitting the job. There is no binding for TaskToolboxFactory in CliOverlord like CliPeon. It seems linked to the change you did in IngestSegmentFirehoseFactory.java https://github.com/vigiglobe/druid/commit/853f1c2305f2f1d68686f8a2567aa835c59aa658

Yes, that's what I was thinking. Once im in the office I'll get a new patch

Now it seems to work, it's now running for more than 5 hours for one day of data. It's too slow. I ran a batch ingestion on the same machine and it took me 2 hours.
I will investigate batch ingestion using Indexing service with raw data. It will avoid all problems related to segment partitioning.

I don't think Firehose ingestion has anywhere near the parallelism of
hadoop.

@cheddar  : Updated the file loading _partially_. Now java-util at least propagates an object which contains some extra information.

Going through, though I couldn't really get a handle on what information would be helpful to the pullers or omni-segment-loader other than the size of data written to disk. If you can think of any particular abstraction that would be helpful, please let me know, otherwise I can simply make a pojo containing the size and use that if you want at least some level of future proofing.

@cheddar : Added a basic datatype to the return of the method in LoadSpec

Also added basic sanity check to the SegmentLoader which checks the expected vs the written size of the segments and logs a warning.

@xvrl @cheddar I'm trying to add setup for more InputRowParsers inside indexing-hadoop . 
I have added a class called MapWritableInputRowParser which can parse MapWritable into InputRow

Please see MapWritableInputRowParserTest.testDeserialization() , currently it is failing. One way, I know of fixing it is to make indexing-hadoop a druid extension module
that is, create a DruidModule implementation in indexing-hadoop and provide appropriate JacksonModule from getJacksonModule() impl and create io.druid.initialization.DruidModule file in indexing-hadoop/..METAINF/..

is there any other smarter way to do it? May be just adding some annotations on the MapWritableInputRowParser class?

update: now that the segment has gone to historical node, we now see a permanent data loss from 14:00 to 14:08

![](http://content.screencast.com/users/PrashantDeva/folders/Jing/media/49d0ba6c-24d6-4cc0-9697-b1a44fc0ff9e/2015-03-15_1547.png)

Hi @pdeva ,

As you may already be aware, the Kafka firehose is a Kafka high level consumer, and within the firehose are a set of configuration options for Kafka. One of the configurations is auto.offset.reset. According to the Kafka docs for this config:

What to do when there is no initial offset in Zookeeper or if an offset is out of range:
- smallest : automatically reset the offset to the smallest offset
- largest : automatically reset the offset to the largest offset
- anything else: throw exception to the consumer. If this is set to largest, the consumer may lose some messages when the number of partitions, for the topics it subscribes to, changes on the broker. To prevent data loss during partition addition, set auto.offset.reset to smallest

Given that Kafka has no real notion of timestamps, Druid has no way of reading messages from exactly at the beginning of an hour. The firehose needs to start at some offset in Kafka, and in this case, it started reading messages from an offset corresponding to events that were ingested at around the time the node started up. I agree we should do a better job of documenting this possibility.

even in the case where node 4 couldnt read data from the begining of the hour, node 3 clearly had the entire data for the full hour.
This is evidenced in the video i linked where refreshing sometimes shows the full data.

in that case, why didnt druid pick the node that has all the data to persist to deep storage?
will write up more UTs covering bySegment groupbys tomm.

made indexing-hadoop a druid extension to register MapWritableInputRowParser as a subtype of InputRowParser inside jackson framework
What is the impact to performance of groupBys?
Collections.synchronizedList(..) will effectively serialize all access. If we can use a Queue instead of List here(seems like we can) then ConcurrentLinkedQueue might perform much better.

this is a reproducible issue.
i can add a realtime node in the middle of the hour.
the broker is then free to pass it any query it for the hour, even though it doesnt have the data for the full hour.

this all happens when there are other replica realtime nodes containing the full hour's data
it seems like this is related to a different issue. closing for now.

- Can we replace MySQL with Metadata Storage? People often get confused by that and dismiss Druid thinking it's just built on top of MySQL.
- We might also want list both Samza and Storm as the stream processor piece.

Other data solutions have a setting for how many input rows can be bad before a job fails, and often have a way to store the bad rows in their own output so they can be cleaned up later.

Is this expected to be bad because the row had a read error or because the data itself is corrupt?

How to deal with the bad rows properly depends on the data set and individual requirements, and so it should be configurable. At minimum though, if they're set to be ignored, I think it's a good idea to log them somewhere (perhaps a file?) for debugging purposes. For my particular use case, there's nothing I can do with the bad rows other than ignore them, since the some of the fields in the log lines are externally-generated.

My change in this PR is to simply honor the `ignoreInvalidRows` flag that is specified in the indexer config file, which already works for the mappers.

@dkharrat : can you make the title of the PR something more like "Honor `ignoreInvalidRows` in hadoop indexer"

This helps signify this as a bug rather than a feature enhancement.

Semi-related issue: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/1045

Can you share what the ingestion spec looks like with regards to dimensions and metrics which are in the query?
Also please include what version you are running in the issue description.
@haadcode : Thanks, we are looking into this to try and make sure we understand why userId is showing up as a Double in IncrementalIndex

The plumber is supposed to be created at runtime rather than provided by the user, because the index task needs a special plumber to work properly. It actually used to be that you couldn't specify a plumber at all, but that got changed in the config refactoring. Now, you can, but it should be null so the task can create its own.

I believe the problem here is because the groupBy engine in 0.7.0 finalizes results when it really shouldn't have. Are you able to test against master?

The specific fix is https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1044/files#diff-631de2c7bba9484c3ffd4a58b4cf691eR198 I believe

@dkharrat this code is already there in HadoopDruidIndxerMapper which honors the "ignoreInvalidRows" configuration. Reducer will not even get the record if there was a problem with parsing it.

@drcrallen done, I updated the title.

@himadrisingh001 yes, the mapper also ignores malformed records, but it only parses the line based on the ParseSpec and doesn't parse the individual column values. In my case, I had a perfectly valid CSV line (so mapper succeeded in parsing it), but the column value was invalid (an integer was expected for a particular column, but got a string instead), so when the index tries to parse the column value, an exception is thrown. My change handles that case.

Generally looks good to me.  I think there is room to move the parsing entirely into the InputFormat and just pass an `InputRow` into the MR jobs, but I don't think there's too much value in holding this up for that.
thanks @dkharrat that sounds reasonable. i agree with @drcrallen on including parser.parse inside try-catch block.

@himanshug : awesome thanks :)

So the issue is that files ending in `SNAPSHOT.jar` were getting constantly overwritten by concurrent jobs with equal HDFS distributedClassPath settings, which was causing issues.

You mentioned in https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/druid-development/ucDX9iTKjiM that this was caused by hadoop-lzo being a SNAPSHOT. Is that just because you guys are forced to use a SNAPSHOT for some reason? Or am I missing some point in the vanilla druid where we're pulling in a SNAPSHOT?

Also, it will only get cleaned up if leaveIntermediate is false (if i'm remembering this correctly)

Nice debugging by the way.

The reason I ask is because, in general, SNAPSHOT jars should not be used in a production environment, and a workaround would be to have your own version of hadoop-lzo (like lzo-hadoop-1.0.4-nicktate1) which isn't a "SNAPSHOT.jar" 

Alternatively a different workingPath can be set for development oriented hadoop jobs. 

This PR gets rid of a handy production feature at the expense of what is arguably a development use case. Which we can do, but need really good justification on why workarounds are not sufficient.

So the snapshot jar was an oversight when copying the jars from the
EMR hadoop classpath. I still consistently received Lease mismatch
exceptions when jobs tried to concurrently retrieve jars from the classpath. It seems like different containers are trying to access the jars but they lease them before retrieving which causes issues when running simultaneously.

```
org.apache.hadoop.ipc.RemoteException(org.apache.hadoop.hdfs.server.namenode.LeaseExpiredException): Lease mismatch on /mnt/druid-indexer/classpath/hadoop-common-2.4.0-amzn-3.jar owned by Container_1622335545_1 but is accessed by Container_1561990512_1
```

@nicktate : As per the hadoop docs https://hadoop.apache.org/docs/current/api/org/apache/hadoop/fs/FileSystem.html#create(org.apache.hadoop.fs.Path), `FileSystem.create` overwrites by default. In this case it looks like multiple jobs reach the file copy step concurrently. So they all find the file missing and try to copy the missing files over. It seems to me that the correct thing to do here would be to disable overwrite on the create, and handle the race condition.

The case that would need to be taken into account is if the race winner fails to properly upload the file.
Or copy to the job's directory, and do a rename which is set to fail on overwrite.

it is clear that 2 jobs can't simultaneously write same file on hdfs so *SNAPSHOT.jar needs to be avoided.

but after removing SNAPSHOT.jar, it is still unclear why two MR jobs can't read same jars (on same path) concurrently. I wonder if this is a known hadoop limitation or a bug?

it may be ok/cleaner to have different place to store jars for different jobs. however, it also means that same set of jars will now need to be copied over to hdfs everytime a hadoop indexer task runs. so, it needs to be seen how much time it takes to copy all jars.

@himanshug : I had just commented as you were typing your response it seems :) I suspect multiple jobs are trying to do the file _copy_ at the same time, making the error at copy time, rather than at concurrent read time.

@drcrallen yeah :) , after reading your comment I see the race condition that even without SNAPSHOT.jar, two threads might still end up writing same jars.
I think if time to upload jars everytime is negligible(say less than 1-2 minute) compared to typical batch job runtimes then simple solution proposed by @nicktate in this PR is good enough and simpler than trying to look after race condition and other failure scenarios(i.e. case when race winner fails to upload file etc)
I think it's also worth looking into @drcrallen's suggestion of disabling overwrite.

ok, this fixes the build. I don't know whether to wait for original bug to get fixed or put this in the RouterJettyServerInitializer.java also. (this bug might cause router to just block if jetty server is not initialized with enough threads)

what do you think?

@gianm @cheddar I'm trying to understand this one and looking at the code. though I could understand the problem and both proposed solutions. but, I am having hard time understanding the problem with implementing option-2 that is "optimize size of inverted indices" . can u pls explain this a bit more?
any update?
I should have time this week to run a few tests on an optimized solution.

@himanshug I think nobody actually does this, but, in principle you could choose a dimension ordering that creates more runs in the earlier columns and that would make compression work better for those columns.
Adding a thread limit without a way to record the usage seems risky. Is it possible to add the number of used threads as a metric or something?
Also, can you add a unit test so behavior can be defined for what happens if the thread count limit is met? This might require making the limit configurable.
In the short term, if there's a way to make this as big or larger than the servlet executor pool would at least provide some limit compared to prior behavior.

@himanshug thanks for tracking this down! I wonder if this affects the router as well or not. I'm a bit puzzled as to why this test started failing, since we didn't change any of that code or updated jetty. Something on the Travis end must have changed that triggers this bug, maybe the default number of threads is tied to the number of cores, and that may have changed.
@himanshug do you mind adding a comment above the line you added to refer to the bug? I'll merge after that.

As a general FYI, it looks like this behavior is still present in [9.3.0](https://github.com/eclipse/jetty.project/blob/jetty-9.3.0.M2/jetty-proxy/src/main/java/org/eclipse/jetty/proxy/AbstractProxyServlet.java#L244-L259) but in a different place than referenced in the original ticket.
